subsection.p: To multiply two fractions together, we multiply their numerators together and then multiply their denominators together.

statement.p: Use the fundamental principle of fractions to explain why the shortcut strategy is valid.

answer.p: We can multiply or divide the numerator and denominator of a fraction by the same nonzero factor, and the new fraction will be equivalent to the old one.

subsection.p: The shortcut strategy also works on algebraic fractions.

assemblage.title: Look Closer
assemblage.p: When we multiply algebraic fractions, it is usually easier to cancel common factors before multiplying. Otherwise, it may be very difficult to reduce the result!

ol.li: Factor each numerator and denominator completely.
If any factor appears in both a numerator and a denominator, divide out that factor.
Multiply the remaining factors of the numerator and the remaining factors of the denominator.

subsection.p: So far we have considered fractions whose numerators and denominators are monomials. The next example illustrates how to multiply fractions whose numerators and denominators are binomials.

subsection.p: If we want to multiply a fraction by a whole number, we can write the whole number with a denominator of 1. For example, \dfrac{2x}{3} \cdot \blert{4} = \dfrac{2x}{3} \cdot \blert{\dfrac{4}{1}} = \dfrac{8x}{3}

subsection.title: Quotients of Fractions
subsection.p: To divide one fraction by another, we multiply the first fraction by the reciprocal of the second fraction. For example, \dfrac{m}{2} \blert{\div \dfrac{2p}{3}} = \dfrac{m}{2} \blert{\cdot \dfrac{3}{2p}} = \dfrac{3m}{4p}

Why does this rule for division work? Consider a simple example, 6 \div \dfrac{1}{3}. This quotient asks us "how many one-thirds are there in six?" To see the answer, we can draw six whole units as shown below, and split each into thirds.

Because there are 3 thirds in each whole unit, we find 63, or 18 thirds in six units. The answer is 18. Now, 3 is the reciprocal of \dfrac{1}{3}, so by using the reciprocal rule, we also find 6 \div \dfrac{1}{3} = 6 \times 3 = 18

assemblage.title: Look Closer
assemblage.p: For a more interesting example, you might try using the figure above to show that 6 \div \dfrac{2}{3} = 6 \times \dfrac{3}{2} = 9 (Hint: How many groups of two thirds can you make from six whole units?)

statement.p: Explain why dividing a number by \dfrac{1}{3} is the same as multiplying the number by 3.

answer.p: Dividing by \dfrac{1}{3} asks "how many one-thirds are there in the number?"

subsection.p: To divide two algebraic fractions, we take the reciprocal of the divisor and then follow the rules for multiplying algebraic fractions.

assemblage.title: To Divide One Fraction by Another

ol.li: Take the reciprocal of the second fraction and change the division to multiplication.
Follow the rules for multiplication of fractions.

subsection.p: Just as with multiplication, it is important to factor each numerator and denominator before trying to cancel any common factors.

warning.p: In Example 4, do not try to cancel before factoring the numerators and denominators! For example, it would be incorrect to try to cancel a^2 before factoring each binomial.

subsection.title: Adding Like Fractions

assemblage.p: Fractions with the same denominator are called like fractions.

subsection.p: We can add or subtract two fractions only if they are like fractions, for the same reason that we can add only like terms. For example, 3x+4x=7x becuase 3x and 4x are like terms. Similarly, we can think of the sum \dfrac{3}{5} +\dfrac{4}{5} as \blert{3}(\dfrac{1}{5})+\blert{4}(\dfrac{1}{5})=\blert{7}(\dfrac{1}{5}) = \dfrac{\blert{7}}{5}

assemblage.title: Look Closer
assemblage.p: In the example above, the denominators of the fractions tell us what kind of quantity we are adding (namely, fifths). We can add only quantities of the same kind. Note that we added the numerators, 3+4, but kept the same denominator, 5.
When we add like fractions, we add their numerators and keep the denominator the same.

warning.p: In the example above, we do not add the denominators of the fractions; only the numerators. It would be incorrect to write 6x for the denominator of the sum.

statement.p: How do we add like fractions?

answer.p: Combine the numerators over a single denominator.

subsection.title: Subtracting Like Fractions
subsection.p: We must be careful when subtracting algebraic fractions: A subtraction sign in front of a fraction applies to the entire numerator.

assemblage.title: To Add or Subtract Like Fractions

ol.li: Reduce the sum or difference if necessary.

statement.p: When we subtract like fractions, how do we apply the subtraction sign?

answer.p: To each term of the numerator of the subtracted fraction.

subsection.title: Polynomial Division
subsection.p: If an algebraic fraction cannot be reduced, we can simplify it by dividing the denominator into the numerator, just as we do with arithmetic fractions. The quotient will be the sum of a polynomial and a simpler algebraic fraction.
If the denominator is a monomial, we can simply divide the monomial into each term of the numerator.
